titleStmt.title: Ethiopic MS 11: Dersāna Mikā'ēl (Homilary for the Festivals of St Michael): Digital edition
titleStmt.funder: The John Rylands Research Institute and Library, The University of Manchester

address.addrLine: The John Rylands Research Institute and Library

addrLine.ref: The John Rylands Research Institute and Library

summary.p: This manuscript is comprised of a collection of homilies for the festivals of St Michael together with stories about the miracles performed by the archangel. Among its contents are a calendar for fixing the movable feasts across seven cycles of nineteen years, as well as thirty-two miniatures in Gondar style illustrating the miracles of St Michael.

msItem.title: History of the Archangel St Michael
Homily of Demetrius, Patriarch of Alexandria
msItem.incipit: በስመ ፡ ... ድርሳን ፡ ወነገር ፡ ዘቅዱስ ፡ አባ፡ ደማቴዎስ ፡ (sic) ሊቀ ፡ ጳጳሳት ፡ ዘእለ ፡ እስክንድርያ ፤ ዘይትነበብ ፡ በበዓለ ፡ ቅዱስ ፡ ሚካኤል ፡ አመ ፡ ፲ወ፪ ፡ ለወርኃ ፡ ኅዳር ፡ …

msItem.title: Miracle for this festival
msItem.incipit: ተአምሪሁ ፡ ለሚካኤል ፡ ክቡር ፡ ሊቆሙ ፡ ለመላእክት ፡ ወአስተበቍዎቱ ፡ የሃሉ ፡ ምስለ ፡ ፍቁሩ ፡ [...] ለዓለመ ፡ ዓለም ፡ አሜን ። ተብህለ ፡ ከመ ፡ ሀሎ ፡ ፩ ክርስቲያን ፡ እምአበይተ ፡ ሮሜ ፡ ወመካን ፡ ብእሲቱ ፡ ወኢወለደት ፡ ጥቀ ፡ ግሙራ ። …
msItem.note: A sterile woman bears a son through the intervention of St Michael; she devotes her child to service in St Michael's church.

msItem.title: Appearance of St Michael to Joshua
msItem.incipit: በስመ ፡ … አመ ፡ ፲ወ፪ ለኅዳር ፡፡ በዛቲ ፡ ዕለት ፡ ተዝካረ ፡ በዓሉ ፡ ለመልአክ ፡ ክቡር ፡ ሚካኤል ፡ ... ዝንቱ ፡ ዘርእዮ ፡ ኢየሱ ፡ ወልደ ፡ ነዌ ፡ ወውእቱ ፡ በክቡር ፡ ዓቢይ ፡ …

msItem.title: Mälkǝ' of St Michael
msItem.incipit: ሰላም ፡ ሰላም ፡ ለዝክረ ፡ ስምከ ፡ ምስለ ፡ ስመ ፡ ልዑል ፡ ዘተሳተፈ ።

supportDesc.support: Book block made of parchment with an unusually coarse texture.
supportDesc.extent:
152 folios (ii+152+ii) of two sizes. Folios 5-6: 240 205 Folios 7-146: 242 210
258 230 102

foliation.p: Modern pencil foliation in Arabic numerals on the upper right corner of each recto folio.

collation.p: Sections are composed primarily of 4 bifolios. The main manuscript containing folios 7-146 is composed of fifteen quires. It is preceded by a double flyleaf (folios 5-6) containing a calendar for fixing the movable feasts.

layout.p: Folios 7r-146v: Two columns, 18 lines per leaf.
Folios have been pricked and scored to assist in writing. Black and red manuscript writing ink.

handNote.p: Written in a Ge'ez script, in black and red ink.

decoNote.p: Thirty-two miniatures in a fine Gondar style, thickly painted in vivid pigments: reds, yellows, greens, browns, dark blues and black.
Most of the illustrations are protected by pieces of fine muslin sewn at the tops of their pages.
The miniatures on 18v, 19r, 19v, 30r, 30v, 35r, 35v, 46r, 46v, 54v, 64r, 64v, 86r, 86v, 103r, 103v, 110r, 123r, 123v, 130v, 146v, 147v, 148r, 148v, and 149v illustrate the miracles of St Michael.
The rest of the miniaturs are as follows: 2v, St George killing the dragon; 3r, Virgin Mary and Christ Child; 4r, Magesti Domini; 150r, a man taking a book in his right hand with a necklet and cross.

additions.p: Some page edges have silk thread markers sewn through about a quarter of the way down (to mark the beginning of each festival). They alternate in colour between red and blue silk. Many are now lost. There is a loose bookmark made of strip of a multicoloured printed textile tucked into the book block.

Illuminated folios have curtains of a thin, open weave textile (possibly cotton). These are attached via stitches through the head of the page, usually with thread, but silk ribbon has also been observed. Textile curtains are in poor condition - often torn, folded, occasionally detached from the page, and ingrained with dirt.
On the lower margin of 14r, a short magical prayer.
On the lower margin of 152v, a circle with magical text written in a spiral.

binding.decoNote: Linen chemise was included that acts as an additional protective cover with a strip of linen attached at head of the spine to wrap around the exposed edges of the textblock. Appears as if it was sewn to fit the dimensions of the book. The chemise is ingrained with dirt, the sewing is strained with unhemmed edges becoming frayed, and the wrapping strap becoming creased, frayed and worn.
binding.p: Ethiopic binding with unusual inclusion of a hollow. Full leather bound in reddish brown goat leather with blind tooled decoration. Thick wooden boards. The turn-ins of the leather covering are extended further on the inner boards, with an added strip of leather along the spine edge, to create a panel space in the centre of the inner boards that has been lined with a green silk textile. Red leather split braid endbands. The anchoring is different from usual. The head and tail of the spine have been lined with separate pieces of very thin leather. The leather spans the spine and onto the boards, and is turned in over the boards and itself, with the flesh side facing outwards, and extending down the spine no further than the first sewing stations. These pieces form headcaps over the braided leather. The anchoring sewing is sewn through these lining strips and the covering leather placed over creating a hollow. Unsupported sewing at 4 stations (two even pairs of sewing stations). The sewing is laced into the boards as an integral part of the sewing process and is done in separate pairs with each pair sewn using a different thread.

provenance.p: The original owners Täklä Alfa (cf. 7r and throughout) and his wife Säbänä Giyorgis (cf. 34v and throughout) have been erased. The name of the second owner is Gäbrä Mika'el. Another owner is Wäldä Le'ul Haylu, named in a note on 152v: ዝንቱ ፡ ድርሳን ፡ ዘወ[ል]ደ ፡ልዑል፡ ኃይሉ ፡ ዘተሰየጦ ፡ በንዋዩ ፡ ከመ ፡ ይኵኖ ፡ መድኃኒተ ፡ ነፍስ ፡ ወስጋ ፡ ዘሰረቆ ፡ ወዘፈሐቆ ፡ በሰልጣነ ፡ ጴጥሮስ ፡ ወጳውሎስ ፡ ለይኩን ፡ ውጉዘ ፡. The name Habtä Mika'el is found in the inscription placed under the picture on 150r: ዘጸለየ ፡ ሀብተ ፡ ሚካኤል. The name Haylä Sǝllase is mentioned in a short magical prayer in the margin at 14r.

James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847-1913) . The first folio (pastedown) bears the armorial bookplate (Ex Libris) identifying the codex as having once been part of the Bibliotheca Lindesiana, the private library of the Lindsay family, Earls of Crawford and Balcarres | Armorial bookplate (Ex Libris): ARMS: Quarterly, 1st and 4th, Gules a fess chequy Argent and Azure; 2nd and 3rd, Or a lion rampant Gules, debruised of a ribbon in bend Sable. CREST: a swan’s head, neck, and wings proper, issuing from an antique ducal coronet Or. SUPPORTERS: two lions, rampant guardant Gules. MOTTO in Latin: Endure fort (Endure bravely) | Bibliotheca Lindesiana | pencilled: 5/G. Pencilled on upper left corner of 1v: Ethiopic MSS | No 11.
Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847-1913).

acquisition.p: Bequeathed by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1908 to The John Rylands Library.

availability.p: The item is available for consultation by any accredited reader.
For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Using Special Collections at the John Rylands Research Institute and Library.
For further information on the availability of the item, please contact the Special Collections Reader Services.
